msgSnippet: Thanks you all for your replies. My first question has definitely been well answered, I ll experiment with the different methods of testing these private
messageBody:
Thanks you all for your replies.

My first question has definitely been well answered, I'll experiment
with the different methods of testing these private fields.



Now on to the second question:

Much of the programming that I do is network related. This includes
passing messages from server to client and even implementing some
firewall capabilities.

Lets take the firewall api provided my Microsoft as an example:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/rras/rr
as/packet_filtering_functions.asp
<http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/rras/r
ras/packet_filtering_functions.asp>

If I implement a simple firewall application that say blocks all
outgoing http traffic. It would be nice to apply the advantages of JUnit
to this code also.



Is this possible?

If MockObjects are the answer, could somebody please give me a reference
to some introductory material regarding this.

I've done some reading on MockObjects but find all the material hard to
understand and I'm still failing to see how I'm going to apply
MockObjects to test my network methods.



Thanks again.

Pico



________________________________

From: Andrew McDonagh [mailto:andrew.mcdonagh@...]
Sent: 10 February 2005 12:33 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Testing certain types of methods



Pico Geyer wrote:

>Hi
>
>I'm a little confused on how to test certain types of methods.
>Is JUnit supposed to be able to test all types of methods.
>
>For example how do you test a:
>1) Method that only modifies private fields and has no corresponding
>getter method to see if the field is now at the correct value
>
>

There must be some form of change in the system, aside from the internal

private fields being modified, use this to verity the public method
worked as expected.

>2) Methods that work on network traffic, ex counting all TCP packets
>that I receive. I would need an isolated environment and would need to
>be able to send X amount of packets to my machine.
>
>

This is where MockObjects come into play.
